transcription.text: Some of the biggest set pieces in film and TV are actually the smallest. Sometimes big scenes are too complicated or expensive to film with huge, life-size sets so production teams create detailed miniatures of locations and settings, and then use camera techniques to trick the audience into thinking they’re seeing the real thing. This model represents that approach and references schlocky 1950s sci-fi films, like It Came From Outer Space (1953) and The War of the Worlds (1953), which often used miniatures for their out-of-this-world plots. Miniatures have since been used in blockbusters like Star Wars (1977), Alien (1979) and Batman (1989). Often, they’re created just to be destroyed – like the White House in Roland Emmerich’s Independence Day (1996).

Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité ("truthful cinema") and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.

work.title: Mikhail Kaufman in Dziga Vertov’s Chelovek s kinoapparatom (Man with a Movie Camera)

transcription.text: This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet. Michelle Yeoh described her win for Best Actress as a beacon of hope for Asian audiences everywhere. In an Oscar's first, Yeoh became the first Asian woman to win the award in its history, only the second woman of color to take home that award ever. Halle Berry, the first WOC to win in the same category over 20 years ago, presented the award.

work.title: Michelle Yeoh wins Best Actress at Oscars 2023: ‘Beacon of hope’

transcription.text: At this year’s Golden Globes awards, Michelle Yeoh finally gained the recognition she deserves with a Best Actress Award for her role in Everything Everywhere All at Once. Footage of her jokingly telling the ceremony producers to “shut up” has gone viral as she brushed off attempts to cut her acceptance speech short. The actress said “I’m just going to stand here and take this all in. 40 years… I’m not letting go of this."

work.title: Michelle Yeoh at the Golden Globes
